can anyone explain , the concept of number of frames being power of 2? please

Rather than using the RTT concept... The simplest is the following!! Here we get answer in just 2 steps.   Tp = Lt seconds Tt = K/R  ==> So no. of bits in the sequence for sliding window protocol is        --> log (1+2a)   Where  a = Tp/Tt      --> log ( 1+2 ( Lt * R/ K ) )     --> log (( K + 2Lt * R) / K )  Ans..

Kindly watch video number 61, Topic name=Go-back-N-ARQ

K is not the number of frames, it is the number of bits in a frame. 2LtR is the total number of bits present across the channel at any given time. A message is broken into frames while transmitting i.e, N number of frames can be transmitted simultaneously in a sliding window protocol. We are finding that N. So bandwidth-delay product(2LtR) divided by K (number of bits in a frame) gives us the number of frames(N) that can be sent simultaneously from the sender before receiving an acknowledgement.

Tp = Lt seconds Tt = K/R  ==> So no. of bits in the sequence for sliding window protocol is        --> log (1+2a)   Where  a = Tp/Tt      --> log ( 1+2 ( Lt * R/ K ) )     --> log (( K + 2Lt * R) / K )  Ans..
